question: [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/config.rs] [Field: propagate_dependency_limit_error] [Error handling] Can failing to propagate dependency limit errors allow attackers to bypass dependency depth limits? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/config.rs] [Field: propagate_dependency_limit_error] [Consensus divergence] Can validators with different propagate_dependency_limit_error settings handle errors differently causing divergence? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/config.rs] [Field: propagate_dependency_limit_error] [DoS] Does silently ignoring dependency limit errors allow attackers to load arbitrarily deep dependency chains? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/config.rs] [Field: enable_framework_for_option] [Default value] Default is true - can disabling framework Option support break system contracts? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/config.rs] [Function: default()] [Insecure defaults] Are the default values security-tested, or can using default() in production introduce vulnerabilities? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/config.rs] [Function: default()] [Security assumptions] Do default values assume test environment with lower security requirements? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/config.rs] [Function: set_paranoid_ref_checks()] [State consistency] Can calling set_paranoid_ref_checks mid-execution cause inconsistent checking for different transactions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-vm/runtime/src/config.rs] [Struct: VMConfig] [Backwards compatibility] The comment mandates 'always add new fields to the end' - can violating this during upgrades break deserialization causing node crashes? (High)
